application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Is Faster Really Better? An Empirical Test of the Implications of Innovation Speed Eric H. Kessler and Paul E. Bierly, III

Abstract-New product innovation is critical to the competitive advantage of many firms. However, there is much hoopla, but little evidence, regarding the benefit of innovation speed. Specifically, there exists insufficient, often conflicting evidence about how dimensions of innovation strategy (cost, quality, and speed) relate to one another and how they ultimately affect project success. Evidence from 75 new product development projects clearly indicates that speed is positively related to quality and has the greatest influence on success. However, several external and firm-level factors were found to moderate the effect of innovation strategy dimensions on project success. Results point to the fact that relationships between dimensions of innovation strategy and project success vary with level and source of uncertainty, with the clearest finding being that speed leads to success primarily in more predictable contexts. This suggests that a fast-paced innovation strategy is best when "you know where you're going." Index Terms-Competitive advantage, demographic dynamism, development cost, environmental uncertainty, innovation speed, new product development, product quality, product radicalness, technological dynamism, technology sourcing.

T HERE is a growing stream in the innovation literature ex- tolling the virtues of speedy development [9], [17], [32], [45]. The pressures for speed in the workplace and the subsequent need for managers to make decisions faster in high-velocity environments are bringing speed to the forefront of managerial thinking. This is particularly true for the management of innovation, because innovation speed is important to first-mover and fast-follower strategies [34]. Innovation speed is defined as the time elapsed between: 1) initial development efforts, including the conception and definition of an innovation; and 2) ultimate commercialization, which is the introduction of a new product into the marketplace. It can be viewed as one of three dimensions of innovation strategy, with the others being quality and efficiency [32].

Notwithstanding the growing interest in this topic, innovation speed has been one of the least studied factors in the new product development literature [40] and among existing studies there has been little empirical evidence with regard to its bottom-line implications [6], [37]. Thus, Crawford [11] comments that "so far we have seen too much specious reasoning and hoopla (about innovation speed) and not enough hard data." Whereas most re-search on speed focuses on the process (i.e., the "how do you go faster" question) [9], [31], [36], we instead examine its strategic implications (i.e., "what happens when you go fast").

Looking for a moment at the larger picture, successful new product development is among the most pressing challenges facing firms today, especially those in high-technology environments. New product development is a critical component of competitive strategy because it can be a used to leapfrog competition, create entry barriers, establish a leadership position, open up new distribution channels, and garner new customers to improve market position [6], [50]. Due to shortening product life cycles, the strategic importance of new product innovation is growing to address new competitive, technological, and consumer challenges [46], [50]. Although much has been written on factors that influence the success or failure of product innovation (e.g., [9], [25], [31]), few researchers have empirically considered the relative influence of dimensions of innovation strategy-efficiency, quality, and speed [6], [46]-on new product success [40]. As stated previously, this is especially true with regards to speed.

Despite the scant empirical attention on the implications of innovation speed, or perhaps because of it, the literature advances inconsistent predictions with regards to the relationships of innovation speed with other dimensions of innovation strategy, and with the overall success of a new product development project. For example, while many argue that increasing the pace of innovation reduces development costs [38], [42] and improves product quality [50], some claim that there are instead trade-offs between innovation speed and 1) the costs of development, since it may take more resources to get the product out earlier [11], and 2) the quality of the product, since increasing speed may entail reducing performance specifications [45]. Further, there is an additional unresolved issue regarding the contextual dependence of speed's benefits [32]. Specifically, the effects of external (e.g., technological and demographic environment) and internal (e.g., technology sourcing and product radicalness) factors are important to consider because they have been shown to influence the positioning and posturing of firms [3], [12], [26] and their innovation strategy [8], [17], [46].

Thus, our research question is threefold. 1) How is innovation speed related to the other dimensions of innovation strategy-quality and efficiency? 2) How does innovation speed influence project success? 3) Is the relationship between innovation speed and project success moderated by external and internal levels of uncertainty?

div.head: I. THEORETICAL MODEL AND HYPOTHESES
div.p: This study represents a partial test of Kessler and Chakrabarti's [32] conceptual model of innovation speed. Although this model suggests a number of possible linkages, in this paper, we focus on innovation speed and its relationship with major project outcomes (cost and quality) and project success. We also consider how level and type of uncertainty may moderate these relationships. The hypothesized relationships are displayed in Fig. 1.

div.head: A. Effect of Innovation Speed on Other Dimensions of Innovation Strategy
div.p: The literature assessing the relationships between dimensions of innovation strategy is loosely connected and often contradictory. While it has been shown that speed, cost, and quality are highly interrelated [38], the nature of their interrelation is debated. We make the falsifiable argument that speed, quality, and cost efficiency are synergistic. That is, a speedy process will cost less and better fit customer needs. This is consistent with the prevailing "positive bias" for speed.

Speed and Quality. A quality-based strategy may be at odds with a speed-based strategy because, for high-quality products, firms may refrain from freezing specifications early and instead change them to incorporate new technologies as they become available [25], [46]. However, we propose a positive relationship between speed and quality, defined as the degree to which a product satisfies customer requirements [20], [42]. First, faster development tends to be associated with higher rates of employee learning and the construction of relevant competencies [17], [38]. Second, speed improves the accuracy of forecasting because firms are required to project environmental and technological forces into a shorter time period [45], thus making for a better customer fit. Third, reduced time-to-market allows more advanced components to be incorporated and faster products can, thus, be perceived as more current (i.e., cutting edge) than competitor products [10]. These arguments point to a synergistic relationship between speed and quality.
Hypothesis 1: Innovation speed and product quality are positively related.

div.head: Speed and Costs.
div.p: A cost-based strategy may be at odds with a speed-based strategy because firms may have to "pay for speed" by committing more man-hours, materials, and/or equipment to projects [25], [35]. Also, accelerating innovation processes can burn resources through additional paralleling and communication expenditures. However, a negative relationship between speed and development costs, defined as a project's total financial requirements and human resources expenditures [18], [42], is postulated. First, increased paralleling and more intense communication bring about higher levels of self-consciousness and increased efficiency of resource utilization [6]. Second, faster speed actually provides a cap upon man-hours and other fixed costs [27], [42]. Third, faster speed has been linked with increased coordination and subsequent reductions in costly work redundancy, errors, and recycling [38]. However, there may be a -shaped relationship between time and cost, such that faster speed reduces cost up to a point and then requires greater investment. Even if this is true, we contend that most projects are on the right, upward sloping side of the " " (too long), insofar as they do not push the bounds of speed and have room to reduce costs. Thus, we propose a synergistic relationship between speed and cost.
Hypothesis 2: Innovation speed and development costs are negatively related.

div.head: B. Effects of Innovation Speed on Project Success
div.p: We argue that innovation speed will have a substantial positive impact on project success. Innovation speed represents the capability of firms to move quickly from ideas to actual products, increasing the potential to realize first-mover advantages. Lieberman and Montgomery [34] clearly outlined specific firstmover advantages, including the ability to:

1) legally exclude followers through patents or copyrights; 2) charge initial premium prices, which produce profits that can be used to further improve products and processes; 3) preempt competitors concerning access to scarce resources, critical suppliers, and key distribution channels; 4) develop a reputation as a leader; 5) set the industry standard; 6) build a cost advantage through economies of learning. Innovation speed is also important for followers' firms to be successful, by limiting some of the first mover advantages of the leader. In fact, a study by McKinsey et al. found that new products that come to market six months late, but on-budget, earn 33% less profit than if they were on time, while new products which come to market on-time, but 50% over budget, earn only 4% less profit than if they were on budget [32]. With regard to market share, speed can help establish early segments and customer loyalty [21], [46] while combating product obsolescence [10], [38]. In this vein, Gomory [21] comments, "one cannot overestimate the importance of getting through each turn of the (product development) cycle more quickly than a competitor. It takes only a few turns for the company to build up a commanding lead."
Hypothesis 3: Faster innovation speed will have a positive influence on project success.

div.head: C. Effect of External and Internal Contingency Factors
div.p: It is unwise to view the relationship between innovation speed and project success in a vacuum, because the interaction of the market and firm environment shape both strategy and performance [26]. Unfortunately, shortcomings in this area are evidenced by the lack of multilevel studies of innovation [40]. In this study, we propose that the relationship between speed and project success is moderated by organizational uncertainty. Indeed, many external and internal dimensions influence uncertainty, including complexity, threat (e.g., discontinuities), instability (e.g., dynamism), and interconnectedness (e.g., sourcing) [14]. There is a multitude of potential perspectives on the speed-uncertainty relationship, for example that uncertain demand might put a "premium" on speed or warrant greater caution and better intelligence before one commits to action. Our basic premise is based in the latter, specifically that the link between speed and success is weaker when there is high uncertainty. We base this primarily on the increased forecasting error (less information is available), increased "noise" (shifting rules of the game), and shorter time to reap benefits during highly uncertain conditions (assailed and obscured profit windows). Together, greater uncertainty will reduce speed-based advantages because the direction of the speedy endeavor is less likely to be appropriate. That is, it is less advantageous to go fast if you can't see clearly and could be going the wrong way.

To measure external uncertainty, we use environmental dimensions used by Wheelwright and Clark [50], and others: technological dynamism and demographic dynamism. Both of these constructs can be viewed as different dimensions of environmental uncertainty, meaning they influence the firm's ability to predict future market conditions. Technological dynamism, which refers to the rapid development and change of technology within an industry, creates market uncertainty by frequently changing the dominant designs and standards of the industry [47]. In such quickly changing environments, advantages are only temporary as all firms in the industry are aggressively trying to capture the market [12]. Speed advantages may be nonexistent if a competing dominant design emerges, and even if speed does create advantages they are usually quickly matched or improved on by competitors. Of course, during conditions of high technological dynamism, all successful firms must be able to move rapidly to compete [12]. However, pushing faster and faster during these conditions does not necessarily increase project success because of the high degree of uncertainty in hitting ones target. Demographic dynamism refers to changing needs of customers due to social trends, population shifts, and changes in income and educational levels [32]. These rapid changes in the demographic environment shorten product life cycles and create fleeting windows of opportunity [45]. Similar to previous arguments, speed will only contribute to the success of new products if the firm can properly forecast and meet future demographic trends.
Hypothesis 4: Innovation speed will have a more positive influence on success when external (technological and demographic) uncertainty is low than when external uncertainty is high.

Firm-level factors also moderate the relationship between innovation speed and project success such that greater internal un-certainty makes it difficult to successfully pursue a speed-based strategy. We study two such factors, product radicalness and technology sourcing. First, new product development projects can be categorized by their radicalness or degree of attempted advancement, where more radical innovations are newer to the focal organization and represent a greater departure from existing practices [13]. Radicalness is a widely used and typically acknowledged contingency factor because the processes, structures, and outcomes involved in radical and incremental innovations are different [22]. Radical innovations are much more risky than incremental innovations, and are particularly problematic for established firms because new dominant designs and standards are often based on new, less familiar areas of technical expertise [47]. Whereas radical innovations promote "creative destruction" and uncertainty for these firms, incremental innovations strengthen their advantages, reduce uncertainty, and lead to more predictable success [1].

Second, the relative balance of internal and external technology sourcing also influences uncertainty. Internal sourcing (e.g., corporate R&D), by its nature, is a more risky venture and its success is less predictable. Externally sourcing established technologies (e.g., via alliances or licensing) is a safer, more predictable approach since the technology has usually been developed and tested. Thus, given the lower uncertainty of external sourcing, innovation speed should be a better predictor of success for externally-sourced innovations than for those that are internally-sourced. Moreover, since competitors may also have access to the external source of technology, speed is an even more critical differentiating factor for external than internal sourcing. However, it is important to note that successful external sourcing can only occur if the firm has already internally developed "absorptive capacity" so that it can effectively understand and apply the external knowledge [8]. Thus, in the long term, a balanced sourcing approach is needed to maximize the learning and efficiency of the organization [3].
Hypothesis 5: Innovation speed will have a more positive influence on success when internal (radicalness and sourcing) uncertainty is low than when internal uncertainty is high.

div.head: A. Research Sample
div.p: The selection of the research sample is motivated by the objective of being able to generalize the findings of this study beyond 1) the idiosyncratic nature of undeveloped, unconventional product development programs and instead across organizational boundaries, and 2) the idiosyncratic nature of one or two business environments and instead across industry boundaries. As a result, the sample consists of large companies (more likely to have established new product development programs) in a variety of industries (to have provided access to a range of task and institutional environments where product innovation is pursued). Given these criteria, thirty companies were chosen that met the criteria of the study and were headquartered locally, which was a practical research constraint (e.g., travel resources). A letter was sent to the chief executive officer or top research and development executive (e.g., VP, R&D) of these firms, which provided a general overview of the study, ex-plained the nature of the commitment requested, and detailed the benefits of participation. Two to three weeks after these letters were sent, direct telephone calls were made to these individuals to answer any questions they had about the study and arrange a mutually convenient time for an on-site interview (to secure commitment). Ultimately, this resulted in a sample of ten large, U.S.-based companies (names withheld due to confidentiality agreements, averaging approximately 90 000 employees and $16 billion in sales) operating in a variety of industries: advanced/ scientific materials, chemicals/chemical materials, confectionery/consumer goods, industrial equipment/products. 1 The unit of analysis was the new product development project. This is because adopting a project level of analysis, defined as "a goal directed effort with a readily-identified end in view" [43], enables the study to capture unique situational attributes that influence the processes and outcomes of actual projects [15]. A total of 86 projects were drawn from ten companies. Of the 86 products selected for the study, questionnaires representing 75 projects were returned (87% response rate): 25% from advanced/ scientific materials; 19% from chemicals/chemical materials; 40% from confectionery/consumer goods; and 16% from industrial equipment/ products. 2

div.head: B. Data Collection Procedure
div.p: Data were collected using a detailed questionnaire instrument containing scales for independent and dependent variables relevant to the previously described propositions. Data gathering proceeded in several stages, and at each research site, a variety of people provided responses according to the specific information required [19]. First, cooperation of the companies serving as field sites were secured from top management (e.g., CEO or VP R&D) through telephone and personal interview. Second, once on-site, a principal contact person and/or a staff specialist was interviewed to jointly develop a list of projects that fit the objectives of the study. This was to insure that projects 1) were all recent and fully completed within the past five years, 1 The way in which companies were selected means that sample is not completely random. As a result, findings should be interpreted in the strictest sense as applying only to those companies in the sample. However, since a relatively broad cross-section of industries was studied, the study's findings may be generalizable to some degree to firms in these industries (Cooper & Kleinschmidt, [18]). 2 Because projects were drawn from several companies from different industries, tests for between-group differences in speed were undertaken. Separate analysis of variance procedures and post-hoc Tukey multiple-comparison procedures revealed that 1) there were between-company differences (F = 3:48; p < :01), with the average speed of projects for two companies (#6 and #3) significantly slower than the other companies, and 2) there were between-industry differences, (F = 7:55; p < :01), with the average speed of projects from the chemical/chemical products and confectionary/consumer products industries significantly faster than those from the advanced/scientific materials and industrial equipment/products industries. Thus, strictly speaking, the results are generalizable only to the specific firms and industries represented in the sample because of the divergent nature of macro-level context. That is, company and industry may be important variables to consider. However, to the extent that differences were in response to general variations in external environmental uncertainty, generalizability might not be so limited. In fact, the results might be more generalizable because it is harder to find significant effects that hold across different company and industry contexts (especially divergent ones) than it is to find significant effects within a single company or industry. Additionally, sampling projects from companies and industries varying in speed might be beneficial for avoiding restriction in range problems.

2) contained significant technological components, 3) were seen as typical for their respective companies. For each company, we requested that about half of the projects were perceived as "relatively successful" and the other half "relatively unsuccessful" as to increase the likelihood of obtaining variability on the primary variables. Moreover, examining several projects from each firm (versus only one or two) provides a more representative picture of the firm's overall new product development program and is less likely to result in a sample of exception and outlier projects, which would restrict the range of the sample.

These interviews also provided a list of the project leader and, when available, one marketing person and one technical person directly involved on each of the project development projects chosen. Multiple respondents were polled for each project to increase the validity and reliability of retrospective reports [2], [33]. Surveys were mailed to the contact persons for distribution to the respondents and then mailed directly back by the respondents. 3 To aggregate the individual responses to the project level of analysis, one-way analyses of variance were used to test intraproject variance [30]. This is necessary to address the "perceptual agreement problem" of using multiple informants [29], [33]. Respondents' scores were aggregated into project scores via unweighted average when there was low rater disagreement (i.e., nonsignificant -scores). Notwithstanding, since the theory and hypotheses require a project level of analysis, aggregation may be appropriate without statistical justification [29], [30]. Therefore, when there was significant disagreement, the project leader's information was used with the assumption that they were the most familiar with the project [36], [37].

The nature of the data collection (retrospective responses to both independent and dependent variables via mailed questionnaire) raises the issue of common methods variance problems. Of course, in collecting data through mailed questionnaires, a trade-off is made with respect to efficiency (e.g., lower cost, time, and staff requirements) versus accuracy (e.g., lower degree of objectivity in the data). In this vein, Fowler [19] reports that there are four basic reasons why survey respondents may report events with less than perfect accuracy: 1) they do not know the information; 2) they cannot recall the information; 3) they do not want to report the information; 4) they do not understand the questions. While no precautions can completely eliminate these potential problems, several actions were taken to limit them. To the issue of knowledge level, respondents were jointly selected to identify those that were most knowledgeable about the specific projects being studied. Additionally, by providing respondents with a relatively lengthy time period for response (several weeks or, in some cases, months), they were given the opportunity to con-sult with archival sources of data (e.g., progress reports) to support their responses on appropriate items. To the issue of information recall, only relatively recent projects were requested (i.e., fully completed within the past five years). To the issue of willingness, participants were informed that their organization would receive feedback on the study's findings. In addition, a written confidentiality policy assured participants that the names of individuals, projects, and firms would remain anonymous and only reported in the aggregate. To the issue of clarity, the questionnaire was piloted by several individuals experienced in new product development. It was then revised as per information gained through pilot testing before being administered to the research sample. For example, questions were sharpened and information was added to facilitate respondents' understanding. Additionally, included with the survey were detailed instructions, definitions of key terms, and the names and phone numbers of researchers to contact if they had any questions.

Moreover, various checks were undertaken to limit such bias resulting from sampling the same individuals for both independent and dependent variables. Projects with single respondents tend to be more vulnerable to this bias, given the single perspective. One might also expect project leaders to be more vulnerable to social desirability bias, given their overall responsibilities and motivation for impression management. Analysis of variance procedures revealed that there were no significant between-group differences 1) at the project level of analysis, for projects with one, two, or three respondents, and 2) at the individual level of analysis, for type of respondent (i.e., leaders, marketing members, and technical members). While not perfect, these checks suggest limits to common methods variance problems. In addition to these methodological steps and statistical checks, we have followed Parke [41] and others in performing Harman's post-hoc single factor test. If a substantial amount of common method variance exists in the data, a single factor will emerge from factor analysis when all variables are entered together, or a general factor that accounts for most of the variance will result. The results of unrotated factor analysis revealed neither a single factor nor a general factor, suggesting that the threat to validity posed by systematic variance common to the measures is lacking.

div.head: C. Measurement of Variables
div.p: Innovation Speed. This was operationalized through three items utilizing 13-point scales:
1) relative to schedule, or "on-time performance" [36], [37];

2) relative to similar completed projects in ones organization, or "acceleration" [11], [25]; 3) relative to similar projects of competitors, or "competitive speed" [46]. The use of 13-point scales was borrowed from McDonough's [36], [37] measurement of innovation speed relative to time goals 4 . We copied this scale and, to be consistent, amended it for our other two measures of speed as well as the corresponding measures of cost and quality. The fact that we used relative measures enabled us to compare dissimilar product development projects [9]. The scales had a moderate degree of internal reliability 0.6824) and loaded onto one factor with eigenvalues equal to or greater than one. Thus, an aggregate innovation speed variable was derived, weighted by factor scores, ranging from one (slowest speed) to 13 (fastest speed).
Development Costs. This was also measured using three items utilizing 13-point scales, mirroring speed. A project's cost was measured relative to:
1) budget;

2) similar past projects; 3) similar competitor projects. The three scales had a moderate degree of internal reliability 0.6173) and loaded onto one factor with eigenvalues equal to or greater than one. Thus, an aggregate development cost variable was derived, weighted by factor scores, ranging from one (lowest cost) to 13 (highest cost).
Product Quality. Quality was also measured through three similar items utilizing 13-point scales, but relative to:

1) preset performance specifications, 2) similar past projects, 3) similar competitor projects. The three scales had a moderate degree of internal reliability 0.7825) and loaded onto one factor with eigenvalues equal to or greater than one. Thus, an aggregate product quality variable was derived, weighted by factor scores, ranging from one (lowest quality) to 13 (highest quality).

Project Success. This was measured using two five-point Likert scales. First, internal success was measured by asking to what extent the project met expectations and attained organizational goals, ranging from not-at-all to completely [48]. Second, external success was measured by asking to what extent the project was a marketplace success-i.e., to what extent did it "win" in competitive situations, ranging from product-flop to completely-successful [22], [23]. The two scales had a moderate degree of internal reliability 0.6839) and loaded onto one factor with eigenvalues equal to or greater than one. Thus, an aggregate project success variable was derived, weighted by factor scores, ranging from one (least successful) to five (most successful).

Technological Dynamism. This was measured through a five-point scale asking the degree to which the respondent would characterize the technological environment of this innovation-e.g., advances in research and development of new products, devices, and processes-ranging from very dynamic (changing rapidly) to very stable (virtually no change) [48].

Demographic Dynamism. This was measured through a five-point scale asking the degree to which the respondent would characterize the demographic environment of this innovation-e.g., social trends, population shifts, income and educational levels-ranging from very dynamic (changing rapidly) to very stable (virtually no change) [48].

Project Radicalness. This was measured through 1) a sixpoint scale asking respondents to evaluate the type of work done on the project, ranging from pure applications engineering to the development or application of new technology [37], and 2) a four-point scale asking respondents to evaluate the degree of change involved in the project, ranging from an imitation of existing products to a radically new product [5]. These responses were pooled with a score of ten indicating a high degree of radicalness and two indicating low radicalness.

Internal Sourcing. This was measured on two five-point scales asking to what extent 1) ideas for this product and 2) technological developments for this product came from internal sources (i.e., members of the research and/or development staff) as opposed to external sources (i.e., capital goods, suppliers, licensing arrangements) [37]. These responses were pooled with ten indicating a high degree of internal sourcing and two indicating low internal sourcing.

div.head: III. ANALYSIS AND RESULTS
div.p: As Table I indicates, projects were, on the average, slightly faster than the midpoint of their scales (about 10% faster than benchmarks); however, they ranged from very fast (about 75% faster) to very slow (about 75% slower). Cost and quality had broad ranges and central means. Projects tended to be on the average quite successful, although they represented all values on the measurement scale. 5 Measures of external and internal uncertainty also had central means and broad ranges. On the average, external contexts were slightly below scale midpoints (moderate-to-low uncertainty) whereas internal contexts were slightly above midpoints (moderate-to-high radicalness and internal sourcing). 5 Project success underwent a square-transformation due to negative skewness-i.e., there was a disproportionately large number of projects with high levels of success (SPSS, 1994: 336). Bobko [4,p. 152] states that "Transformations can clearly reduce the impact of outliers and help allay concerns about violating assumptions of normality and homoscedasticity." Although not excessive, this reinforces the earlier warning of nonrandomness.

To test Hypotheses 1 and 2, bivariate correlation analysis was used to quantify the strength of the association between the strategic dimensions of speed, quality and cost. Supporting Hypothesis 1, there is a positive and statistically significant correlation between process speed and product quality .345 .01 . In other words, faster development time is related to higher quality products. Hypothesis 2 is not supported since the correlation of speed and cost is not statistically significant. However, though not significant, speed was found to be negatively related to cost, as predicted.

To test Hypothesis 3, correlation analysis and multiple linear regression (MLR) analysis were used to test the relationship between speed and project success. 6 The former test determined there is a positive correlation between project success and process speed 0.433 0.01 , supporting Hypotheses 3. The MLR analysis, illustrated in Model 1 of Table II, determined that only speed significantly increases success 0.39 0.01 . Thus, Hypothesis 3 is supported by both methods. The full MLR model was significant 0.05 and explained 20% of the variance in project success.

To test the moderation effects proposed in Hypotheses 4 and 5, we used two different, but complementary, techniques: 1) a series of MLR models using the interaction terms of variables to account for the moderating effects; and 2) a series of split-sample MLR analyses using median splits to compare two 6 Regression models were also run, but are not displayed, with 1) the squared terms of speed, quality and cost to test for nonlinear relationships, and 2) the interactions of speed, quality and cost. In these models, the R was not increased significantly and none of the additional terms were significant. Further tests verified that the technological dynamism, demographic dynamism, and internal sourcing moderating effects were monotonic [44]. The radicalness moderating effect was nonmonotonic but the inflection point (9.72) was barely within the 2-10 variable range.

div.head: TABLE II SELECTED REGRESSION MODELS WITH THE SQUARE OF PROJECT SUCCESS AS THE DEPENDENT VARIABLE. STANDARDIZED REGRESSION COEFFICIENTS DISPLAYED
div.p: different groups of projects. 7 Each of these techniques possesses certain limitations but provides different insight into the relationships being studied and has distinct theoretical meaning. The MLR analysis with interaction terms determines whether there exists a moderating effect between two variables. The hypothesis is supported if the regression coefficient for the interaction term differs significantly from zero. The significance of all the interactions combined is tested by analyzing the change in the model . Inherent in this type of analysis are high levels of multicollinearity, particularly between the independent variables and the interaction terms, which may cause difficulty in interpreting results [16], [49]. For this reason, and for the fact that the relative influence of the main and interaction effects cannot be compared, this type of analysis is best used only to determine whether there is an existence of an interaction effect [49]. The split-sample MLR analysis, which also tests for a moderation type of relationship, relies on splitting the sample into two subgroups based on a contextual factor, and comparing standardized regression coefficients between an independent variable and a dependent variable for each group. The hypothesis is supported if the difference in regression coefficients is sig-nificantly different, as determined by a -test [7]. Whereas, the MLR analysis with interaction terms is best for determining an existence of a moderation effect, the split-sample MLR analysis is best for testing the strength of moderation [49]. However, the split-sample MLR analysis is less robust than other techniques since the quantitative values of the moderating variable are not being used in the analysis.

Table II reports the results of the MLR analyses with interaction terms. Models 2, 4, 6, and 8 add to the baseline model (Model 1) one of the moderating variables proposed in Hypotheses 4 and 5: technological dynamism, demographic dynamism, project radicalness, and internal sourcing, respectively. In all of these models, the does not increase significantly and none of the additional terms are significant. This indicates that the main effect of none of these variables influences project success. In each of the subsequent models (Models 3, 5, 7, and 9), the moderating variable and the interactions of the moderating variable with Speed, Quality and Cost were entered into the model. 8 In three of these (3, 5, 7) models, the increased significantly and interaction terms were significant, supporting the proposed effect of the moderating variables. Overall, it is observed that speed consistently exerts a strong, positive influence on project success. Table III reports the inferential statistics from the split-sample MLR analysis. It was found that all four moderating variables influence the relationship in the proposed direction. For each model, speed is highly and significantly related to project success only in the more predictable, less uncertain situations-low technological dynamism 0.50 0.05 , low demographic dynamism 0.57 0.05 , low product radicalness 0.60 0.01 , and low internal sourcing 0.82 0.01 . The regression coefficients for speed are significantly different between the low and high uncertain contexts for demographic dynamism, product radicalness and internal sourcing (each at the 0.05 level). These findings provide partial support for Hypotheses 4 and 5 and can be interpreted as implying that speed leads to success, but only in contexts where uncertainty is not too high. In other words, speed is good if you know where you are going. The significant findings concerning the moderating effects of demographic dynamism and product radicalness are consistent with the MLR analysis with continuous variables. The overall regression models for all of the less uncertain contexts were significant or marginally significant and better predicted project success than the models for the more uncertain contexts. All of the overall regression models with more uncertain contexts were not significant. The two most powerful models were with low product radicalness 0.01 0.59 and low internal sourcing 0.01 0.63 .

IV. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION New environments are forcing managers to abandon traditional approaches to strategy and search for new approaches to restore competitiveness to their firms [12]. Innovation is a critical part of modern strategies, yet there is a lack of empirical support concerning factors that influence new product performance [40]. This study seeks to address these issues by testing the outcomes of innovation speed in a sample of 75 projects. With regard to the first research question (Hypotheses 1 and 2), correlation analysis revealed that faster innovation speed is associated with higher product quality. Thus, there was not a trade-off between speed and quality; on the contrary, the two dimensions were symbiotic. This supports the notion that fast speed facilitates product quality (or vice versa), perhaps due to the hypothesized synergistic issues of learning, accuracy, and updated technology. It is also possible that this relationship is due to a third variable, perhaps the extent of technical barriers encountered. Notwithstanding, this finding is important because it suggests that one of the strategic goals can be pursued without necessarily sacrificing the other. On the other hand, development costs are not significantly correlated with speed, which was proposed in Hypothesis 2. This indicates that even though there is not a tradeoff between costs and speed, they are not symbiotic.

With regard to the second research question (Hypothesis 3), regression analyses revealed that in the projects studied, innovation speed is the most critical determinant of success. The main effects of quality and costs on success were significant only in a few regressions that added interaction terms. Since speed and quality were correlated, the regression results do not necessarily contradict those championing a "high-quality" strategy, because fast speed may be an element of a high-quality focus (or vice versa). The finding that speed exerts a greater influence on success than does cost is consistent with Rubenstein et al.'s [43] finding that a project's ability to meet time schedules was significantly related to project success while a project's ability to meet cost estimates was not. It is also consistent with the previously cited McKinsey study. The clearest managerial implication of this finding is that, in this sample, innovation speed more than any other factors drives project success. This suggests that greater management attention should be devoted to increasing new product development speed.

With regard to the third research question (Hypotheses 4 and 5), MLR and the split-sample analyses showed that external and firm level factors moderated the relationship between innovation speed and project success. Three out of four moderating variables are statistically significant using the MLR (technological dynamism, demographic dynamism, and project radicalness) and the split-sample (demographic dynamism, project radicalness, and internal sourcing) methods. All of the significant moderation effects indicate that innovation speed better predicts project success under conditions of less uncertainty. The implications concerning innovation speed are clear: Speed is more effective for more predictable innovations (i.e., less radical, externally sourced) and in more predictable environments (i.e., simple, stable). This implies that, although speed is generally good, it is most functional under low uncertainty. Thus, managers should pursue speed most vigorously when they have a "clear target," that is, when the technology is known and markets can be forecast.

Interestingly, the relationship between development costs and project success was also influenced by our moderating variables. The regression coefficients in the split-sample regression were positive for all low uncertainty conditions and negative for all high uncertainty conditions. Thus, for low uncertainty conditions, especially low technological dynamism, increasing the costs of development produces more successful projects. At first glance, this appears counter-intuitive, because it implies a more inefficient new product development process is linked to success. However, this is probably misinterpreting the results. Alternatively, these results indicate that under conditions of low uncertainty, innovation speed, and to a lesser degree, quality, are so important to project success that firms should not skimp on any costs that may reduce speed or quality. Quite the contrary, firms that spend money to accelerate new product development and improve quality are rewarded. Additionally, these results offer absolutely no support for a cost-based innovation strategy. That is, a strategy where management focuses attention on being efficient in the innovation process is not an effective innovation strategy. They would be better off investing in speed and quality.

Internal sourcing turns out to be a very interesting moderating variable. According to the split-sample regression, internal sourcing significantly moderates the relationships between project success and speed 0.05 , quality 0.05 , and perhaps costs 0.10 ; and the three dimensions of innovation strategy account for more variance of project success when internal sourcing is low 0.63 , than when internal sourcing is high 0.14 . However, a finer analysis of the data reveals some insightful findings. First, the results indicate that speed is crucial to success if one relies more on external sources (Table III, 0.82), but not that important if one relies more on internal sources 0.14 . From a strategic standpoint, this makes sense. Since the technology is obtained via the market and available to all competitors, the firm that can get to market first and take advantage of first-in advantages will clearly have the upper hand. However, correlation analysis reveals that the more firms internally source, the faster will be the innovation process. This is counter to the theoretical reasoning by some researchers, who argue that relying on external sourcing increases new product development speed by limiting the number of internal tasks and redoing what others have already done [32]. What may be missing in this line of reasoning is to realize the difficulty in bringing outside technologies into the organization, interpreting the "foreign" knowledge, and integrating the different knowledge areas with the organization's knowledge base [8]. Thus, speed, sourcing, and project success have a complicated, intertwined relationship. Project speed increases the more an organization internally sources, but fast internal sourcing is less important to success due to the uncertainty of the new idea. Alternatively, when externally sourcing, speed is critical to success. Thus, firms face the challenge of speeding up knowledge integration processes when external sourcing.

Second, the split-sample regression (Table III) and the regression with interaction terms (Table II) provide different results when internal sourcing is used as the moderating variable; it is a strongly significant moderating variable using the split-sample regression, but it is not when the regression with interaction terms method is used. This apparent contradiction is addressed by Venkatraman [49] who explains that these two methods, while both testing for a moderating effect, actually test for different types of fit. Split-sample regression best indicates the predictive ability of certain strategies across different environments, and the regression with interaction terms best indicates performance when it is jointly determined by the interaction of the predictor and the moderator. Thus, the classification of internal and external sourcing as two different contexts is valuable for determining when innovation speed will be more or less effective, but internal sourcing and innovation speed do not jointly determine project success via their interaction across the entire range of internal sourcing.

Overall, the results of this study inform both academic and practical concerns. First, they offer scholars empirical information regarding much discussed, but less frequently tested, relationships between innovation speed and other project outcomes. In this sense, the study represents a partial empirical test of Kessler and Chakrabarti's [32] conceptual model of innovation speed. Specifically, the results suggest that speed of a new product innovation is generally positively related to its eventual success, however, a contingency relationship exists insofar as the consequences of a fast innovation vary with levels of internal and external uncertainty. These findings also have implications for the management of innovation. The results inform managers that pursuing speed in innovation need not be at the sacrifice of lower cost or higher quality; in fact, there does not seem to be a necessary tradeoff between these objectives. However, it is probably better to strain for speed not as an end but rather as a means toward improved cost and quality performance. That is, firms should pursue focused improvements in speed as opposed to blind haste. This is similar in spirit to Deming's insight that pursuing higher quality need not be at the sacrifice of lower costs [20].

Of course, there are limitations to the study that necessitate a provisional approach to these findings and suggest further avenues for research. For instance, the reliability coefficients for the measures were only moderate, the sample size was relatively small within the context of the statistical analyses, and the interrater reliability was less than desirable. These all require that the interpretation of the results be more conservative and provide motivation for future research to replicate and ex-tend the study. Additionally, several of our scales were single or double-item measures (e.g., project success, internal sourcing) and could have been richer. There is also the issue of how dimensions of innovation strategy failed to predict success in uncertain environments. To this point, there may be additional explanatory factors, perhaps based in the institutional environments of firms. Additionally, there is the issue of time-perspective when assessing new product success. Hultink and Robben [28] argue that in the short-term firms tend to emphasize speed, whereas meeting quality guidelines were both a short-term and long-term concern. Thus, our findings might reflect time-bound conceptions of new product success.

Moreover, there is the issue of culture on assessing new product success. For example, Gupta et al. [24], and Mansfield [35] found differences in how U.S. managers and their German and Japanese counterparts viewed innovation strategy. These differences may be attributed to judgement (i.e., "Japanese" and "German" approaches are superior to a "U.S." cost-driven approach) or to context (i.e., dissimilar demands are placed on projects in different national settings). If the former is true, our findings suggest that U.S. managers should emphasize speed more, especially in predictable contexts. If the latter is true, our findings may not apply outside the U.S. environment.

The outcomes of innovation speed are complex; there are important tradeoffs (and nontradeoffs) and contingency relationships to consider. Perhaps our most important finding is that the "hoopla" surrounding speed is largely justified but needs qualification. Innovation speed is related to higher quality products and increases project success even more so than traditional criteria of high quality and low cost. However, fast-paced innovation is best in more predictable contexts, consistent with the finding that forcing rapid development under high uncertainty may produce failure [39]. Thus, speed is good, but it is better "when you know where you are going."

figure.figDesc: REGRESSION COEFFICIENTS () FOR MAIN-EFFECT AND SPLIT-SAMPLE REGRESSION ANALYSES: THE SQUARE OF PROJECT SUCCESS IS THE DEPENDENT VARIABLE

note.p: Over half of the projects (54.7%) had multiple respondents. Sixty of the 127 responses (47.2%) were from project leaders, with the remaining responses almost equally split between marketing members (34 responses) technical members (33 responses). As indicated, separate analysis of variance procedures revealed that there were no significant between-group differences at the project level of analysis for number of respondents nor at the individual level of analysis for type of respondent.
McDonough asked respondents to assess whether a project was a certain percentage slower (6-levels), equal, or faster (6-levels) than its time goal.
The limited sample size within the context of these analyses restricts the models we consider and makes the results more conservative in nature.
Variable transformations were required in the interaction models to adjust for high levels of multicollinearity.
